Author: mmiller
Content: "Worse Is Better" is an old article, I think from the early 1990s. Back then Lisp did run slowly. I can remember taking a course around 1989/1990 that had us running the n-queens problem in Lisp. People would start up their n-queens programs on Unix minis and leave them running unattended, to go away for lunch or something. The programs ran for hours. This is the reason why Gabriel talks about scale (memory size) and performance. Today these are not really issues anymore. I can run the same n-queens program on my PC and it'll take just a second or two to run. That's a dramatic difference.

Author: Tichy

Author: Tichy
Content:
Eclipse does more than just autocompletions. It also helps you navigate your code for example.

Nevertheless, I think programming without completions sucks. I think most non-IDE editors also try to offer completions, though. It's one reason I can't stand Rails: all that passing around of parameters in Hashes is fundamentally not autocompletable.

Content:

Author: Goladus
Content:
I thought an evidence-based guess was called a hypothesis.

Anyway, my problem with scientific analysis of my work habits has always been the observation phase. I can keep timesheets, but that turns out not to be useful data because I only keep timesheets reliably when I'm full of energy. When I'm full of energy, I'm more productive at everything. \n

Author: Readmore
Content: Joel is an excellent salesman! Based on his article I totally want that feature now, and not only did he make it sound great he also made it sound in-depth enough that I would rather pay for it than waste time trying to re-create it. Very nice.
